stimulusHtml: A newspaper article claims that 92 percent of teens use social media. To investigate the claim, a polling organization selected a random sample of 100 teens, and 96 teens in the sample indicated that they use social media. Given the data, why is it not appropriate to use a one-sample z-test for a proportion to test the newspaperâ€™s claim?
choicesHtml: The random sample condition is not met.
The sample is more than 10% of the population.
The observed number of teens in the sample who do not use social media is less than 10.
The expected number of teens in the sample who do not use social media is less than 10.
The distribution of the population is not approximately normal.
